recipes.title: Grandma's Chocolate Chip Cookies
recipes.description: Classic chocolate chip cookies that have been passed down through three generations. Crispy on the outside, chewy on the inside.
instructions: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
Combine flour, baking soda and salt in a small bowl.
Beat butter, granulated sugar and brown sugar in large mixer bowl until creamy.
Add eggs and vanilla extract; beat well.
Gradually beat in flour mixture.
Stir in chocolate chips.
Drop by rounded tablespoon onto ungreased baking sheets.
Bake for 9 to 11 minutes or until golden brown.
Cool on baking sheets for 2 minutes; remove to wire racks to cool completely.
recipes.notes: Grandma always said the secret is to not overbake them. They should still look slightly underdone when you take them out.

recipes.title: Mom's Sunday Pot Roast
recipes.description: A hearty Sunday dinner staple. This tender pot roast with vegetables is comfort food at its finest.
instructions: Season roast generously with salt and pepper.
Heat oil in a large Dutch oven over medium-high heat.
Brown roast on all sides, about 3-4 minutes per side.
Remove roast and set aside.
Add onions and garlic to pot, sauté until fragrant.
Return roast to pot, add broth, wine, bay leaves, and thyme.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to low.
Cover and simmer for 2 hours.
Add carrots and potatoes, continue cooking for 1 more hour until vegetables are tender.
Remove roast and vegetables, make gravy with pan juices and flour.
Slice roast and serve with vegetables and gravy.
recipes.notes: Mom always made this on Sundays after church. The whole house would smell amazing!
recipes.origin: Mom's adaptation of her mother's recipe

recipes.title: Aunt Mary's Apple Pie
recipes.description: The perfect apple pie with a flaky crust and cinnamon-spiced apple filling. A must-have at every family gathering.
ingredients: 6-7 medium apples (Granny Smith or Honeycrisp), peeled and sliced
2 tbsp butter, cut into small pieces
instructions: Preheat oven to 425°F (220°C).
Place one pie crust in a 9-inch pie dish.
In a large bowl, combine apples, sugars, flour, cinnamon, nutmeg, and salt.
Pour apple mixture into pie crust and dot with butter pieces.
Cover with second pie crust, seal edges, and cut slits in top.
Brush with egg wash and sprinkle with coarse sugar if desired.
Bake for 15 minutes at 425°F.
Reduce heat to 350°F (175°C) and bake for 35-40 minutes more until golden and bubbly.
Cool for at least 2 hours before serving.
recipes.notes: Aunt Mary always used a mix of tart and sweet apples. Serve warm with vanilla ice cream!
recipes.origin: Aunt Mary's famous recipe from the 1970s

recipes.title: Nana's Chicken Noodle Soup
recipes.description: The ultimate comfort food. This chicken noodle soup cures all ailments and warms the soul.
instructions: Place chicken in a large pot with water, bring to a boil.
Reduce heat and simmer for 45 minutes, skimming any foam.
Remove chicken, let cool, then shred meat and discard bones.
Add carrots, celery, onion, garlic, bay leaves, thyme, and parsley to broth.
Simmer for 20 minutes until vegetables are tender.
Add shredded chicken and noodles.
Cook for 8-10 minutes until noodles are done.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Garnish with fresh parsley before serving.
recipes.notes: Nana always said this soup had healing powers. Make a big batch and freeze some for later!
recipes.origin: Nana's go-to recipe for sick family members

recipes.title: Papa's Skillet Cornbread
recipes.description: Golden, crispy cornbread baked in a cast iron skillet. Perfect with chili or bbq.
instructions: Preheat oven to 425°F (220°C).
Place a 10-inch cast iron skillet in oven with oil to heat.
In a large bowl, whisk together cornmeal, flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt.
In another bowl, whisk together buttermilk, eggs, and melted butter.
Pour wet ingredients into dry ingredients and stir until just combined.
Carefully remove hot skillet from oven.
Pour batter into hot skillet.
Bake for 20-25 minutes until golden brown and a toothpick comes out clean.
Let cool for 5 minutes before slicing.
recipes.notes: Papa insisted on using a cast iron skillet - it makes the edges perfectly crispy. Serve warm with butter and honey.
recipes.origin: Papa's recipe from his Tennessee childhood

recipes.title: Great-Grandma's Buttermilk Biscuits
recipes.description: Flaky, buttery biscuits that melt in your mouth. The secret is in the technique.
ingredients: 1/2 cup cold butter, cut into cubes
instructions: Preheat oven to 450°F (230°C).
In a large bowl, whisk together flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt.
Cut in cold butter using a pastry cutter or fork until mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
Make a well in center and pour in buttermilk.
Stir gently until dough just comes together - don't overmix!
Turn dough onto a floured surface and pat into a 3/4-inch thick rectangle.
Fold dough in half, then pat out again. Repeat 2-3 times.
Cut with a 2-inch biscuit cutter, pressing straight down without twisting.
Place biscuits on a baking sheet, touching each other.
Bake for 10-12 minutes until golden brown.
Brush tops with melted butter immediately after removing from oven.
recipes.notes: Great-Grandma's secret: keep everything cold and don't overwork the dough. The folding creates those beautiful flaky layers.
